docs.snippet: Into the thick of Oscar week, comes real, actual science. Well, more like voodoo mixed with some extant metrics, but you have to love the attempt to make the Oscars comport to some sort of logic. The University of Oregon's Iain Pardoe has been cru...
docs.lead_paragraph: Into the thick of Oscar week, comes real, actual science. Well, more like voodoo mixed with some extant metrics, but you have to love the attempt to make the Oscars comport to some sort of logic. The University of Oregon's Iain Pardoe has been crunching the numbers for the past 30 years ad has come up with a statistical model that predicts in four major categories. His predictions happen to match the conventional wisdom, so no great shakes there.

docs.snippet: The Bagger would never bet on the Oscars. Not that he has moral objections; he just generally loses enough in the office pool already as it is. But there those who do and Pinnacle Sports was the first site to set odds on the Oscars, minutes after ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Bagger would never bet on the Oscars. Not that he has moral objections; he just generally loses enough in the office pool already as it is. But there those who do and Pinnacle Sports was the first site to set odds on the Oscars, minutes after the nominees were announced. The Bagger would be hard-pressed to think of something dumber than laying down serious money on the Oscars, but the odds are interesting to those who are handicapping for the sheer intellectual frisson of being right.

headline.main: A Thrill Ride to 'the Other Side of Infinity'
headline.print_headline: Theoretical Physics, in Video: A Thrill Ride to 'the Other Side of Infinity'

docs.snippet: The central goal of Andrew Hamilton's latest project is both simple and mind-bendingly paradoxical: to visualize what cannot be seen....
docs.lead_paragraph: Video game technology and Einstein's work on relativity may at first seem as unlikely a couple as Oscar and Felix. One bobs in the froth of commercial culture, dodging the scornful radar of educators and parents who wish students were off doing something else like, say, studying Einstein. The other is as highbrow as science gets in its lofty waltz of theoretical physics, where time and space warp in otherworldly ways that have given brain aches to generations of physics students.
docs.abstract: Andrew J S Hamilton, University of Colorado astrophysics professor, develops digital presentation using Einstein's equations that takes viewer on flight through black hole; work is based on video game technology and is showing at Denver Museum of Nature and Science Gates Planetarium; black holes discussed; photos (M)

headline.main: Theoretical Physics, in Video: A Thrill Ride to 'the Other Side of Infinity'

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: DENVER MUSEUM OF NATURE AND SCIENCE

docs.snippet: At a time when refrigerators can be programmed to tell you they are out of milk, the Oscars are delineated the old-fashioned way - counted by hand in the same room where they keep Dick Cheney when the going gets tough. In a press release, Pricewat...
docs.lead_paragraph: At a time when refrigerators can be programmed to tell you they are out of milk, the Oscars are delineated the old-fashioned way - counted by hand in the same room where they keep Dick Cheney when the going gets tough. In a press release, PricewaterhouseCoopers lifts up the blankets just a bit on the process, sharing some fascinating Oscar trivia. For example, the fact that it takes "1,700 person-hours each year to count and verify the ballots." For the past 72 years, the "persons" at the accounting firm have guarded the Oscar results with abundant fervor, but that was before the NSA started monitoring domestic phone conversations. The Bagger's sure the boys with the old gimlet eye have taken appropriate measures. Once the ballots are counted, the real black ops begin:

docs.snippet: The business model of Hollywood may be in flux and the future may seem uncertain, but that's no reason to spoil the party. In fact, BizBash, which keeps track of such things, suggests that various swells will drop $150 million on Oscar-related fes...
docs.lead_paragraph: The business model of Hollywood may be in flux and the future may seem uncertain, but that's no reason to spoil the party. In fact, BizBash, which keeps track of such things, suggests that various swells will drop $150 million on Oscar-related festivities. Given the overall budgets of most of the year's nominees, you could make about a dozen movies instead of buying all the shrimp and vodka, but hey, where's the fun in that?

headline.main: And the Money to Pay for It

docs.snippet: Any weekend savant with a dial-up connection can tell you who is going to win in most of the categories, but it takes a rare form of brilliance to figure out who is absolutely, no doubt about it, going to tank come Sunday night. That's the primary...
docs.lead_paragraph: Any weekend savant with a dial-up connection can tell you who is going to win in most of the categories, but it takes a rare form of brilliance to figure out who is absolutely, no doubt about it, going to tank come Sunday night. That's the primary challenge at Drew's Script-O-Rama, where he is offering swag to those who can sense a halo of flies around the big losers. It may be easy to guess that this is not going to be Charlize Theron's year - she's already won and she is in a movie almost no one saw and even fewer are bothering to talk about - but can you say with surety that Robert Elswit has not shot for his cinematography Oscar in "Good Night, and Good Luck"? We thought not. Go ahead, can't lose if you don't play.
